webTitle: Elusive tycoon Kevin Leech and the North Korean mining rights

fields.standfirst: He has a reputation for offering 900% profits by investing in pariah states, but are his sales pitches too good to be true?
fields.body:
There have always been plenty of people interested in Kevin Leech, whose family own Land's End, the Snowdon mountain railway and Reliant cars [see footnote].

During the dotcom boom they came to learn the tactics that prompted him to become an early investor in internet stocks and propelled the Jersey-based businessman to be named as Britain's 17th richest person with an estimated fortune of £1.2bn - as well as the first billionaire to emerge from an island stuffed full of tycoons.

But since those halcyon days - and a now discharged bankruptcy dating back to 2002 - Leech has developed a reputation as an entirely different type of dealmaker – one who can promise 900% profits, almost instantaneously, for investing in pariah states. And who wouldn't be interested in that?

The entrepreneur's re-emergence as a public figure came in 2009 as a major shareholder in First London, the collapsed investment bank that attracted national attention because of its links to convicted insurance fraudster Russell King, plus its role in the short-lived takeover of League Two football team Notts County.

The lowly football league club sensationally signed Sven-Göran Eriksson as its director of football, in return for paying the former England manager €11m (£9m) of shares in a previously unknown First London client called Swiss Commodity Holding (SCH).

The story became even more intriguing when it emerged SCH was claiming to own trillions of dollars worth of mining rights in North Korea and had taken Eriksson to a business meeting inside the "axis of evil". But SCH shares eventually proved worthless as it became embroiled in the £173m collapse of First London (see box).

Some of the First London shareholders upset by the way their investment disintegrated are among the people now keen to be reacquainted with the tycoon. Being a major shareholder himself, he might possess crucial information.

Their problem is finding him in Jersey, as the businessman has moved east, where he has established a new following keen to hear his latest investment theories [see footnote].

Leech's lawyers say he now spends the majority of his time in Asia, as that is where his business interests are, though they insist "Jersey remains his home". But despite the geographical move, there are common themes with SCH, with documents suggesting his recent pitches seem to target millions of pounds from private investors on the back of North Korean mining licences.

Potential new shareholders have been promised tenfold returns in a matter of months, which has started to prompt a recurring question: are Leech's sales pitches slightly too good to be true?

The Guardian has seen numerous documents for multimillion-pound fundraisings by a Leech company, Sunmin Resources, during 2010 and 2011. One, dated December 2010 and prepared by a London-based advisory firm, said the company was attempting to raise £5m and promising investors that "every £1 invested will be worth £10" by the time the company floated in Hong Kong three months later.

The document continued: "Sunmin has just completed on agreements which gives the company 50 year rights to mine world class reserves of precious metals, base metals and rare earth metals in North Korea", which it suggested could be worth in excess of $3tn [£2tn].

Additional selling points included a strong management team that boasted the presence of Leech, the involvement of Macquarie, the global bank, which was said to be representing the company; and, crucially, claims that Sunmin acquired the North Korean mineral rights that were previously held by SCH and its successor company Coremin.

However, the Guardian has also seen a letter sent to Leech as a representative of SCH and Coremin, that predates that presentation by five months. It was written by North Korea's Natural Resources Development & Investment Corporation and stated: "NDIC has the duty to notify the termination and abrogation" of the agreements with SCH, partly because "SCH AG has seriously violated the clauses of the non-disclosure and non-transfer/waiver obligations … by divulging the contents and trying to sell the assigned rights to a third party without any prior consent of NDIC".

When asked specifically about the North Korean letter, Leech did not deny the termination. His law firm McFaddens, also an adviser to Sunmin, said: "The document that you claim to have had sight of dated 24 June 2010, if authentic, was a document which was subject to a strict confidentiality agreement and whoever showed you that document is in breach of that confidentiality agreement."

It added: "For the avoidance of doubt Mr Leech confirms that the Swiss Commodity Holdings [sic] relationship with National [sic] Resources Development & Investment Corporation was terminated by mutual agreement at the end of 2010."

It is not clear if Leech could have acquired subsequent alternative mining rights in North Korea. But when the Guardian asked if he has continued to seek investment for companies that claim to own rights in the country, or if he had continued to be associated with individuals or companies seeking investment for businesses with North Korean rights, he declined to respond.

Meanwhile, the Guardian has seen further documentation dated after the 2010 termination in which Sunmin appears to be selling similar schemes. They include another presentation from early 2011 which outlined the company's plan to raise $10m and stated: "Sunmin currently own rights to mine all precious metals, rare earth elements, rare earth metals and transition metals in five specific provinces of North Korea".

That presentation also claimed Macquarie was acting as the company's banker, where its duties supposedly included advising on the "first public spin out of selected assets on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, with a value to Sunmin at listing of a minimum of $1.5bn". This time the flotation was slated to happen in Hong Kong in the "next 120 days", or was it?

Macquarie says it has never had any agreement with Sunmin, a statement it was only prepared to make after spending days checking its records at its offices around the world. A spokesman for the bank confirmed: "There is no record of Sunmin being a client."

Still, it is not clear who - if anybody - invested in Sunmin, never mind how much.

A search of the Hong Kong stock exchange website unearths zero Sunmin hits. A Google search returns just two results for the company: the first, containing brief details of its Swiss address on the Hoovers business database; and the second, a company registration website, where a 5 April 2011 entry states: "Kevin Ronald Leech establishes Sunmin Resources Corporation AG".

Declining asset

First London was a publicly listed investment bank that included former Conservative minister Tim Yeo and erstwhile head of defence intelligence Air Marshal Sir John Walker among its senior advisers. In 2008 it in effect came under the control of Russell King, a convicted fraudster, who took control of 49% of the bank by claiming he was managing billions of dollars for the Bahraini royal family. After that deal fell through, the company slumped into administration in July 2010 with debts of £8.7m.

Before the collapse, the company had moved its main asset, First London Asset Management (FLAM), to a new holding company and announced its sale to a related group called Swiss Commodity Holding ( SCH) for £173m in 2009. That deal was subsequently modified three times, but independent shareholders have still to receive any of the proceeds. Kevin Leech, a First London shareholder, and the bank said they were victims of King.

In fact, although such a claim was issued in Jersey in 2010, it has never been served on Mr Leech. The article was also amended to remove an incorrect statement that Mr Leech "once owned" Land's End, the Snowdon mountain railway and Reliant cars: they have never been directly owned by Mr Leech, they have always (and still are) held in companies owned by a Leech family trust.

webTitle: Driving us crazy: the weird things we found at the Detroit auto show

fields.standfirst: Pregancy suits, tricked out pool tables, and a violinist steal the spotlight at the North American International Auto Show
fields.body:
Journalists and car enthusiasts from around the world descended upon Detroit for the North American International Auto Show (NAIAS) this week, where some of the world’s most prominent automakers – among them Ford, General Motors, and Toyota – released new designs for their most popular vehicles and previewed the cars of tomorrow.

The vehicles were the main attraction, but there was still plenty at the convention for geeks of all stripes. Scattered among the gleaming trucks, sedans, and sports cars were more than a few weird embellishments, if only you know how to look.

We sent our business reporter Dominic Rushe (@dominicru), who has a keen eye for weirdness, around the NAIAS floor to take photos and videos of all the odd items on display. We also gathered contributions from some of the quirkier auto enthusiasts on Twitter.

Below, we present a small sample of the strange sights at NAIAS

While all of the above items listed here are weird, nothing that follows will even come close to the absurdity and incongruousness of this pregnancy suit.

Someone needs to tell this guy that he’s not at the Consumer Electronics Show.

The smart folks over at Bentley want you to stay connected in style with this utterly superfluous accessory. This handy feature allows you to post obnoxious status updates about how you’re being chauffeured around in a Bentley.

The team from BBC's Top Gear was at the auto show, and have also been on the lookout for strange sights.

While most carmakers opted for turbocharged, hyperbolic presentations (we’re looking at you, Ford), Mercedes used a more subtle approach to attract interest.

Not far from the soothing tones of the violinist, attendees could also relax near an indoor forest.

This thing isn't intended to be driven, right?

… right?

This model might be dressed futuristically, but the idea of using pretty women to sell cars isn’t exactly a revolutionary idea. Yet with most of the human beauties on display were wearing a standard uniform of cocktail dresses and stilettos, we’ve got to give props to this one for really committing.

In case all the hot rods and pickup trucks aren’t enough to make you feel manly, you can play pool on top of a classic car.

And yet, not even a driver's paradise is safe from the encroaching grip of the Bicycle Lobby, which has clearly worked its nefarious magic on the US Labor Department:

Well that's all we got for now. But he show lasts through next week, and we have a feeling the best is yet to come.

Did you spot anything strange at NAIAS, like the guy you see below? Share it with @GuardianUS using the hashtag #WeirdNAIAS.

webTitle: UK brickmakers straining to meet rising demand

fields.standfirst: Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors has warned shortages are a drag on the recovery in building and construction sector
fields.body:
Martin Warner is standing on a pile of nearly one and a half million bricks, stacked several metres high in a vast open shed. Below him pipes of natural gas pump flames into the stack, lighting a fire that will burn day and night for 17 days to bake the bricks at 1080 degrees Celsius, sending the stench of sulphur into the air in billows of steam.

When the whole shed has been set alight, the glowing bricks are left to cool off for a further two weeks. The gas flames are moved on to the next shed, where more "green bricks", moulded from clay are being stacked ready to be fired.

For Warner, chief executive of Michelmersh Brick Holdings, the bustling yard is a welcome sight after the construction sector's deep recession saw brickworks around the country mothballed or closed. Now they are scrambling back into action as the revival in the housing market has led to reports from builders that shortages of bricks and blocks are holding them up. Housebuilder Redrow has highlighted a shortage of roof tiles and skilled workers too.

"There is only so many bricks we can make. We are flat out," said Warner.

It is a picture repeated up and down the country, where many brickworks have kept the fires burning throughout the winter, forgoing the traditional end of year stoppage. Warner's company, listed on the junior Aim market and made up of centuries-old brickworks acquired since the late 1990s, was by no means immune to the downturn. The 300-strong workforce shrank by 100 during the crisis but is back up to 265.

The wider industry went from about 80 brickworks in 2007 to 50 now as demand slumped and manufacturers drove down stocks.

"We have had four years making less bricks than we have sold because there was a stockpile," said Warner.

Then the government's Help to Buy scheme to kickstart the housing market took hold and demand picked up.

"At the time the Help to Buy started picking up in May last year the brick stock reached equilibrium. After five years of grief, of closures, of laying people off, the lights have come on again," said the 60-year-old chief executive, walking around the Freshfield Lane works in Sussex, one of the company's four UK sites. Here wealden clay formed 100m years ago is excavated once a year in early summer and then throughout the year mixed to a special recipe, formed by machine, or sometimes by hand, into bricks for firing.

The whole journey from "quarry to lorry", as Warner puts it, takes 10 weeks. For an industry facing pent-up demand it is a long lead time. At some of Michelmersh's other sites where kilns are used to bake, the process is five to seven days.

The company is investing to make more bricks on the Sussex site. But there is little it can do to cut manufacturing times if it wants the kind of premium bricks that have won it contracts such as supplying the restoration of St Pancras station, says Warner. What he wants to see next is his profit margins recovering after years of rising costs and stagnant prices, an average of 23p a brick for the industry. With haulage, that makes the cost of bricks for the typical 1,000 square foot home £3,000, less than half the cost of a new kitchen.

"We are not all going to be spending loads of money till we get some margin," said Warner, whose own bricks sell for an average of 36p.

For builders, the prospects of supply picking up look slim. Bricks are too heavy to import from far afield, though nearby Belgium and the Netherlands do manage to sell into the UK. Nor does the industry lend itself to new entrants, thanks to the complex manufacturing process, big capital investment required and need for a nearby quarry.

"These are businesses where once they are lost, they are lost," said Warner.

Some believe the shortfall in bricks could have wider repercussions for the economy. A report into the construction industry by the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors last week highlighted materials shortages as a drag on the nascent construction recovery. But the lobby group for materials makers says this is simply a return to more normal supply-demand dynamics.

"Pre-recession, housebuilders were used to planning weeks in advance for materials purchasing. After the recession, with subdued activity levels, housebuilders got used to purchasing a few days in advance," said Noble Francis, economics director at the Construction Products Association."Now, it may be that house builders have to get back to planning construction materials considerably in advance."

Smaller builders echo that. Nathan Beard, who runs NSJ Building Services in south London, said a breezeblock shortage on a recent job had left his team hanging around for three weeks. Finding tradespeople has been even harder. A few years back people came to sites looking for work once or twice a week; now Beard is calling them.

"We needed an extra bricklayer recently and rang eight that we know and they were all too busy," he said."With plasterers it's the same. We can't get the skills for love nor money. I have 10 or 11 contacts and they are all run off their feet. With carpenters, a few stoped carpenting and had to take on other jobs in the recession. The only ones that are not hard to come by are plumbers, we are saturated with plumbers."

webTitle: Tesla close to finishing nationwide network of 'supercharger stations'

fields.standfirst:
• Drivers of Tesla electric cars can across the US for free
  • Network to form chain from Connecticut to Los Angeles
  • Tesla has 'more than 25,000' Model S vehicles on the road
fields.body:
In a few weeks, people will be able to drive across the US for free – as long as they have the $70,000 plus to buy a Tesla electric car.

The Silicon Valley car company started by billionaire Elon Musk announced Tuesday that it is close to finishing a nationwide network of “supercharger stations” that will form a chain from Connecticut down the east coast and on across middle America to Los Angles then up to Vancouver in Canada.

Once weather improves, Jerome Guillen, Tesla’s vice-president of worldwide sales and service, told the Detroit auto show that the company will "plug" the gaps – so to speak – adding supercharger stations in Pennsylvania, Ohio and Arizona. A Model S can travel 300 miles on a full charge.

“I receive dozens of emails every day with people asking me for a supercharger here, a supercharger there,” he said. “We are responding to huge demand.”

The news came as Tesla was once more hit with technical difficulties. On Tuesday the company issued a recall of about 29,000 charging adapters for its 2013 Model S electric cars because of a potential fire hazard.

Guillen dismissed the recall as a “firmware” update and said nothing would have to be physically recalled. He said that more than 99% of the chargers had already been updated. “We are going to be having discussions about using a word that has no physical sense,” he said.

Tesla’s share price spiked 10% after the press conference, suggesting investors had dismissed the recall. It is one of several fixes that the company has had to make. In November federal officials began probing into two battery fires in Tesla vehicles. Half of the company’s Roadster, its first car, were recalled for chassis issues.

Guillen said there were now more than 25,000 Model S vehicles on the road and they had driven 168m miles without a single fatality. “This is one of the safest cars on the road. And we have the evidence to show it,” he said. “We don’t stand still. Although the car is, we believe, extremely safe my colleagues are continuing to think about ways of making it even safer.”

Guillen said the company was getting closer to launching the Model X, its next generation electric car, and would then work on a cut price, mass market model he said would be half the price of the Model S. The company hopes to sell more than 40,000 vehicles in 2014.

Tesla’s Model S is now the best selling car in Norway, which is now fully covered by superchargers and a network that reaches to the arctic circle, said Guillen. He said the company had already built a supercharger network between Amsterdam and the alps and would build a network of charges between Toronto and Montreal “as soon as weather allows”.

A number of new electric cars were launched at the Detroit auto show including new cars from BMW and Mercedes’ Smart. Asked if Tesla feared competition, Guillen said: “The more electric vehicles there are on the street, the better off we are.”
fields.bodyText: In a few weeks, people will be able to drive across the US for free – as long as they have the $70,000 plus to buy a Tesla electric car. The Silicon Valley car company started by billionaire Elon Musk announced Tuesday that it is close to finishing a nationwide network of “supercharger stations” that will form a chain from Connecticut down the east coast and on across middle America to Los Angles then up to Vancouver in Canada. Once weather improves, Jerome Guillen, Tesla’s vice-president of worldwide sales and service, told the Detroit auto show that the company will "plug" the gaps – so to speak – adding supercharger stations in Pennsylvania, Ohio and Arizona. A Model S can travel 300 miles on a full charge. “I receive dozens of emails every day with people asking me for a supercharger here, a supercharger there,” he said. “We are responding to huge demand.” The news came as Tesla was once more hit with technical difficulties. On Tuesday the company issued a recall of about 29,000 charging adapters for its 2013 Model S electric cars because of a potential fire hazard. Guillen dismissed the recall as a “firmware” update and said nothing would have to be physically recalled. He said that more than 99% of the chargers had already been updated. “We are going to be having discussions about using a word that has no physical sense,” he said. Tesla’s share price spiked 10% after the press conference, suggesting investors had dismissed the recall. It is one of several fixes that the company has had to make. In November federal officials began probing into two battery fires in Tesla vehicles. Half of the company’s Roadster, its first car, were recalled for chassis issues. Guillen said there were now more than 25,000 Model S vehicles on the road and they had driven 168m miles without a single fatality. “This is one of the safest cars on the road. And we have the evidence to show it,” he said. “We don’t stand still. Although the car is, we believe, extremely safe my colleagues are continuing to think about ways of making it even safer.” Guillen said the company was getting closer to launching the Model X, its next generation electric car, and would then work on a cut price, mass market model he said would be half the price of the Model S. The company hopes to sell more than 40,000 vehicles in 2014. Tesla’s Model S is now the best selling car in Norway, which is now fully covered by superchargers and a network that reaches to the arctic circle, said Guillen. He said the company had already built a supercharger network between Amsterdam and the alps and would build a network of charges between Toronto and Montreal “as soon as weather allows”. A number of new electric cars were launched at the Detroit auto show including new cars from BMW and Mercedes’ Smart. Asked if Tesla feared competition, Guillen said: “The more electric vehicles there are on the street, the better off we are.”
fields.headline: Tesla close to finishing nationwide network of 'supercharger stations'

webTitle: Unity Trust Bank ownership set for overhaul after Co-op Bank's stake sale

fields.standfirst: Trade unions that own the remaining 73% of Unity Trust have the right to buy any shares sold by Co-op Bank
fields.body:
The ownership structure of Unity Trust Bank – which provides loans to the Labour party – is to be overhauled as a result of the Co-operative Bank's 27% stake being put up for sale.

The trade unions that own the remaining 73% of Unity Trust have the right to buy any shares sold by the Co-op Bank, which is itself being overhauled under the new management team that led last year's £1.5bn rescue deal.

Set up in 1984, Unity Trust is best known for providing banking services to trade unions, charities and local authorities.

Graham Bennett, who chairs the Birmingham-based Unity Trust, said detailed discussions were underway to "reposition the bank as we approach our 30th anniversary".

"The Co-operative Bank has been a fantastic supporter of Unity Trust since it was first founded, however, the time is now right to review our structure as we begin the next chapter of Unity's development underpinned by our distinct approach to banking," said Bennett.

Co-op Bank is facing sweeping job cuts as its new chief executive Niall Bookers attempts to restore profitability following the capital shortfall which led to the rescue by its bond holders – led by US hedge funds – and resulted in the Co-op Group of supermarket, pharmacies and funeral homes ceding control of the bank. It was also hit by the scandal surrounding its former chairman Paul Flowers who is alleged to have bought illegal drugs.

Booker said: "The Co-operative Bank has been a proud supporter of Unity Trust over many years and we will work closely with them through this process, which fits with our own business plan to simplify the bank."

webTitle: UK inflation finally falls to 2% target - as it happened

fields.standfirst:
• ONS: inflation hit UK target in December
  • The details
  • Treasury: economic recovery on track
  • Labour: cost of living crisis not fixed
fields.body:
5.57pm GMT

Over in Greece the government has announced it had achieved the much-cherished target of posting a primary surplus last year which will, it says, make it eligible for debt relief. Helena Smith reports:

After years of pain-staking spending cuts Greece’s central government posted a primary budget surplus of just under €700m in 2013, Athens’ deputy finance minister Christos Staikouras announced in parliament today.

As prime minister Antonis Samaras prepared to fly to Strasbourg where he will formally unveil Greece’s EU presidency plans to the European Parliament, Staikouras said the country was now on target to achieve a total primary budget surplus of around €812m, or 0.4% of gross domestic product at the general government level. Although general government data are not expected to be released for another month “all the indicators show that we will exceed our target,” the minister said, adding that once that happened Athens would be in the market for serious debt relief consideration. 

With the country’s debt burden at an untenable €360bn (more than 175% of GDP) officials say economic recovery will be high nigh impossible until the issue is resolved. Greece’s EU partners and the International Monetary Fund, which have been keeping the nation afloat, have promised to broach the potentially explosive topic once Athens achieves a primary surplus.

Samaras' fragile two-party coalition has pledged to redress slashed pensions and benefits for Greece’s most vulnerable with the extra funds, but Staikouras as is the wont of all politicians in Greece these days avoided going into specifics. 

And on that note, it's time to close up for the evening. Thanks for all your comments and we'll be back again tomorrow.

5.51pm GMT

Another Federal Reserve member has said the US central bank's $75bn a month bond buying programme should be wound down sooner than forecast.

Philadelphi Fed president Charles Plosser, who will be a voting member this year, played down concerns about last week's disappointing jobs data, forecasting more economic growth and a further drop in unemployment in 2014. He said, as reported by Reuters:

As we enter 2014, I think the bottom line is that the economy is on a firmer footing than it has been for the past several years.

In December the Fed made the first move in cutting back its stimulus measures, trimming the bond buying programme by $10bn from $85bn a month. Outgoing Fed chairman Ben Bernanke has said the programme would be wound down in stages, and probably completed altogether by the end of 2014. But Plosser said:

My preference would be that we conclude the purchases sooner than this. But I am glad that we have taken the first step on the path to ending the programme.

5.44pm GMT

European banks will not have to adjust the sovereign debt portfolios they hold to maturity to reflect current market rates, according to an ECB letter signed by president Mario Draghi.

There had been concerns about how these sovereign bonds would be treated in this year's stress tests, and whether rating them at market value could put pressure on bank balance sheets. But the ECB letter, as reported by Reuters, said:

Sovereign exposures, both held-to-maturity [HTM] and available-for-sale exposures, will be included in the stress test although it is not foreseen that HTM portfolios will be marked-to-market.

5.25pm GMT

European markets end higher

After early falls in the wake of an overnight drop on Wall Street, European markets have recovered to end the day on a more positive note. Michael Hewson, chief market analyst at CMC Markets, said:

While last night’s US sell-off seemed to imply that some investors have concerns about high valuations in US markets, European markets have been remarkably more sanguine, despite some early weakness in opening trade, stocks have pared the worst losses after some positive Eurozone industrial production data for November showed a much larger rise than markets had anticipated.

So the closing scores were as follows:

• The FTSE 100 finished 9.71 points or 0.14% higher at 6766.86

• Germany's Dax added 0.32% to 9540.51

• France's Cac closed 0.26% higher at 4274.20

• Italy's FTSE MIB rose 0.17% to 19,730.38

• Spain's Ibex ended up 0.16% at 10,382.0

On Wall Street the Dow Jones Industrial Average is currently 0.48% or 77 points higher.

4.32pm GMT

Spain may sell part of its stake in bailed out Bankia in the first quarter of this year, Reuters reports:

While no decision has yet been made, the economy ministry has recently stepped up contacts with bankers over the possible sale, the sources said.

The state would probably look at selling no more than 18.4%, keeping a majority stake so that the bank's restructuring can be completed by 2017 as agreed with the European Union, they added.

4.23pm GMT

And here's the question observers were waiting for:

Is Valerie Trierweiler still France's first lady?

Hollande plays the privacy card and does not answer directly. See live blog here.

4.21pm GMT

Ahead of the questions:

3.53pm GMT

Francois Hollande has begun his speech, and is concentrating on economic matters so far, saying France must produce more and better, and announcing measures to reduce taxes on companies.

Follow our live blog here.

3.16pm GMT

After Monday's sell-off, partly on comments from a Federal Reserve member suggesting the US central bank would continue trimming its bond buying programme despite weak jobs data, Wall Street has made a recovery in early trading.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average is up around 44 points or 0.3% after better than expected retail sales for December and a positive reaction to JP Morgan's figures (see earlier).

3.01pm GMT

Over in France, Francois Hollande is preparing to give his New Year's speech to the press. Until a few days ago, this was likely to concentrate on the economy, as the country struggles to pull out of recession amid heavy public spending and high taxation. All very worthy and perhaps it would have packed the house out, who knows.

But many of those now gathered to listen to Hollande will be waiting for the president's comments on rather spicier matters, following a report in celebrity magazine Closer claiming he was having an affair with actress Julie Gayet.

If you want to follow the economic debate, or indeed the other issues which may be discussed, we are live-blogging the event here:

Francois Hollande press conference on economy and affair 

Updated at 5.13pm GMT

2.49pm GMT

Back with the UK, and Paddy Power has issued its odds for the timing of the next interest rate rise, with the betting on later rather than sooner:

8/1 first half of 2014

11/2 second half of 2014

11/4 first half of 2015

5/2 second half of 2015

7/4 2016 or later

2.09pm GMT

But there was better news from the Republic, reports Henry:

Ireland has exceeded EU predictions for industrial growth with the Republic increasing its production levels by 13.2% in November 2013 from the year before.

Irish industrial production was the highest in the EU according to the latest Eurostat results on this sector of the economy.

The Irish performance contrasted sharply to the other EU states that were bailed out during the eurozone crisis with Greece suffering the largest decline in industrial output and Spain showing a very small increase in production. 

Meanwhile one of the conditions the IMF and the ECB imposed on Ireland as a price for financial rescue was to drive down its massive public sector wage and cost bill. Even post-bail out the Irish government - in its desire to still be seen as the 'poster child' of the EU - vowed today to save a further €500m in public spending. 

Brendan Howlin, one of the Irish ministers who jointly announced Ireland's exit from the bail out programme in December, said the savings would be made by changing state procurement practices and slashing the pay roll. 

2.05pm GMT

Northern Ireland had the lowest footfall of customers during the Christmas shopping period in the whole of the UK. Ireland correspondent Henry McDonald writes:

Spending in shops during the festive period was almost 9 per cent lower than the previous Christmas.

The figures from the Northern Ireland Retail Consortium showed the drop in spending was nearly 7% more than the overall drop across the UK of 2.4%.

Aside from the recession in the province traders in cities such as Belfast also had to bear the brunt of ongoing loyalist flag protests in the commercial heart of the city including key shopping days coming up to Christmas. In addition there was a flurry of bomb attacks by dissident republicans in Belfast city centre as well as a series of bomb alerts on main arterial routes into the commercial district during the festive season.

As well as political violence and Northern Ireland having one of the lowest incomes per head of population in the UK, retailers say there was a surge in on line purchasing before Christmas. 

Glyn Roberts, of the Northern Ireland Independent Retail Trade Association, described the figures as "disappointing."

He said: "An 8.7% decline is a major cause for concern and we are surprised as a number of our members had reported an increase in footfall and sales in December."

The Northern Ireland Retail Consortium's Aodhán Connolly said: 

"It's deeply concerning to see that Northern Ireland suffered by far the steepest drop in footfall in December, especially after some tentative signs that growth was starting to go the other direction in November.

1.50pm GMT

US retail sales for December came in higher than expected, helping to push Wall Street futures higher in the expectation the economy would continue to strengthen.

According to the Commerce Department, retail sales excluding cars, fuel, building materials and food services, rose 0.7% last month, following a 0.2% rise in November and better than the 0.3% rise forecast by economists.

But if this so-called core figure was better than expected, overall sales grew by just 0.2% given a large decline in sales of automobiles, mainly due to the cold weather. Annalisa Piazza at Newedge Strategy said:

US retail sales came in at a modest 0.2% month on month in December from a downward revised 0.4% the prior month. The outcome for the December print is a touch stronger than expected. We projected retail sales to have remained flat in December following a solid 0.7% gain in November. The downward revision for the latter leaves the overall picture for the fourth quarter of 2013 in line with expectations. On a three month annualized basis, retail sales accelerated to 4.2% from 3.5% in November. However, the fourth quarter pace of growth for retail activity is a touch below the third quarter outcome.

James Knightley at ING said:

With consumer confidence improving and the general state of the economy looking in decent shape, notwithstanding the soft payrolls number last Friday, we remain upbeat on consumer spending prospects and look for the US economy to grow by 3% this year and the Fed taper to continue through to 4Q.

Updated at 2.06pm GMT

1.30pm GMT

Another Wall Street bank, Wells Fargo, has beaten forecasts with a 10% jump in fourth-quarter profits. It made $5.6bn, or $1 per share, in the last three months of 2013.

And on that note, I'm handing over to my colleague Nick Fletcher.

Updated at 1.50pm GMT

1.25pm GMT

Our City editor Jill Treanor has digested today's fourth-quarter and full-year results from JP Morgan, and flags up that average pay rose across the bank last year despite the stream of legal charges and bills.

She reports:

A wave of legal costs and regulatory penalties have dented the profitability of America’s biggest bank JP Morgan and ended a run of record profits.

Becoming the first major US bank to report its results for last year - Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and Bank of America report later this week - JP Morgan admitted its full year profits had fallen 16% to $18bn after a year in which has paid out penalties of around $20bn in total.

The fines have related to the subprime mortgage crisis and its London Whale trading incident in 2012 and Jamie Dimon, who is both chairman and chief executive of the bank, said he was pleased to put “some significant issues behind us this quarter” after reaching settlements with regulators. 

The bank revealed that despite the profits slump the average pay for its 251,000 staff was $122,653 in 2013 - up from $118,000 a year earlier - although within its investment banking arm the average pay was $207,368, down 5% on 2012.

The most recent was last week when it paid a record $2bn to settle charges it had knowingly ignored evidence that convicted fraudster Bernard Madoff’s massive Ponzi scheme was “too good to be true.”

“It was in the best interests of our company and shareholders for us to accept responsibility, resolve these issues and move forward. This will allow us to focus on what we are here for: serving our clients and communities around the world. We remained focused on building our four leading franchises, which all continued to deliver strong underlying performance, for the quarter and the year,” he said.

In the fourth quarter profits fell by 7% to $5.3bn after taking a knock from $1.1bn of legal expenses. But in the third quarter the bank had slumped to its first quarterly loss under Dimon as a result of $9.2bn of legal expenses.

1.20pm GMT

Madoff fines hit JP Morgan's profits

Over on Wall Street, JP Morgan's legal travails have hit its profits again -- and its investment bank didn't have a great quarter either.

JP Morgan kicked off the bank reporting season by announcing that its net income slid by 7% in the last quarter, down to $5.28bn from $5.69bn a year ago.

The results are complicated by the company's latest brushes with regulators -- it just agreed to pay $1.7bn (£1bn) to compensate victims of the Bernard Madoff fraud, the latest in a stream of legal bills.

CEO Jamie Dimon argued that the bank has made progress dealing with its problems. saying:

We are pleased to have made progress on our control, regulatory and litigation agendas and to have put some significant issues behind us this quarter.

Skimming the results, JPM's consumer banking division had a good quarter -- profits on mortgage banking rose 34%.

Investment bank profits tumbled by 57%, although if various one-off accountancy changes are excluded they dropped by a less dramatic 11%.

There are also signs of a slowdown on the trading desks -- fixed income (ie bonds) revenue dropped to $3.2bn, from $4.08bn. Equity markets revenue (such as share trading) fell to $873 million, from $1.3 billion a year earlier.

Updated at 1.29pm GMT

12.50pm GMT

Speaking of London house prices.... we have fresh evidence, not that we needed it, that London's super-rich remain untouched by the cost of living squeeze.

A new tower block is to be thrown up alongside The Shard*, to provide accommodation for well-heeled workers in the Capital. 

And as fastFT flags up, there are 10 apartments up for sale within The Shard itself, "rumoured to be priced at £50m each."

Not clear that any have been sold yet, but the developers must be confident of demand if they're building another (smaller) tower next door.

The FT's Kate Allen wrote:

The new tower, being unveiled at a public consultation today, will include 150 apartments and retail space, as well as a roof garden. The project is being developed by Sellar Property Group in partnership with the state of Qatar.

* - which offers astoundingly beautiful views, only partly because you can't see the Shard from inside

12.24pm GMT

House prices rising ahead of inflation

While the headline inflation rate eased back to 2.0%, house prices have been rising more than twice as fast, according to fresh data this morning.

Strong demand in the south of England drove average house prices up by 5.3% over the last year, the ONS reported. First-time buyers were hit harder, paying 6.4% more than in 2012. 

My colleague Hilary Osborne reports:

The Office for National Statistics said that new entrants to the housing market paid an average of £187,000 during the month – £14,000 more than in the same month of 2012.

The average price paid by movers was higher, at £284,000, which was 5.3% up on 12 months previously, while the average increase across the board was 5.4%.

And London prices led the way, rising by 11.6%.

More here: House prices up across the UK, says ONS

12.10pm GMT

Key event

Here's our news story on today's fall in inflation:

Inflation finally falls to Bank of England's 2% target

12.10pm GMT

UK inflation: a summary

A recap for new readers.

• Britain's inflation rate has finally returned to the government's 2% target, bringing some relief to households and businesses after the long squeeze on living standards.

The Office for National Statistics reported that prices, as measured by the consumer prices index, rose by just 2.0% annually in December. It's the lowest rate since late 2009, and means inflation is in line with the Bank of England's goal.

• Food prices rose by less, the ONS said, while the cost of toys and computer games dropped - suggesting heavy discounting by shops in the run-up to Christmas.
This pushed down CPI, despite energy bills rising as the first winter tariffs hit customers.

• The government hailed the news, with a Treasury spokesman saying that easing inflation meant the UK economy was recovering. Prime minister David Cameron tweeted that hard working families -- a key target demographic for Westminster -- were benefitting.

• But real wages are continuing to shrink, given average pay packets are rising by less than 1%. Labour warned that more needs to be done to help families, such as an energy price freeze and making more free childcare available for working parents.

Catherine McKinnell MP, shadow economic secretary to the Treasury, insists that today's inflation data is no reason to celebrate, given the ongoing cost of living crisis faced by many. 

This small fall in the inflation rate is welcome, but with prices still rising more than twice as fast as wages the cost-of-living crisis continues. After three damaging years of flatlining, working people are on average £1600 a year worse off under the Tories.

• Business leaders welcomed the news, with the BCC arguing that there's no need for the Bank of England to bow to pressure for an early rate rise.

• But as Larry Elliott, our economics editor points out, today's big winners are George Osborne and BoE governor Mark Carney. Most people have suffered a hefty fall in real income since the crisis began -- real wages need to turn positive before the damage can be repaired.

Updated at 12.20pm GMT

11.42am GMT

Today's drop in the Consumer Prices Index to 2% is particularly welcome because high inflation had become the "new normal", says  Andrew Sentance, senior economic adviser at PwC.

Sentance (a former interest-rate setter at the Bank of England) warns that inflationary pressure could intensify through the year.

﻿It’s no coincidence that the fall in inflation over the past year has accompanied a pick-up in growth. Lower price increases ease the squeeze on consumers and allow them to increase spending.

Now that inflation has returned to target, the challenge will be to keep it there. Stronger growth here in the UK could push up wage costs and a rebound in the global economy is likely to push up energy, food and commodity prices once again. So we cannot be sure that this return to the inflation target will be sustained through 2014.


11.06am GMT

Larry Elliott: Osborne and Carney are the big winners

Our economics editor, Larry Elliott, writes that today's fall in the UK inflation rate to the official target of 2.0% for the first time since 2009 is good for chancellor George Osborne and Bank of England governor Mark Carney.

It's "moderately good for the rest of us", he adds.

Falling inflation is welcome news for the Tories with an election around the corner, and also takes pressure off Carney to raise interest rates. But years of high inflation have made a serious dent in living standards - today's inflation data doesn't fix that.

Larry says:

The small decline last month from the 2.1% recorded in November doesn’t sound much, but December saw an increase in petrol prices and the first tranche of price hikes from the “Big 6” energy companies. Price cuts from supermarkets and early Christmas discounting by over-stocked high street retailers helped matters.

The downward trend is likely to continue. Core inflation, the cost of living minus increases in food and fuel prices, dipped from 1.8% to 1.7%, while the cost of goods leaving factory gates – an early sign of price pressures – was up 1% on year earlier. A stronger pound will bear down on the UK’s bill for imports.

It’s pretty clear why this is good news for the chancellor. There are four key measures of how well the economy is doing at a big-picture level: jobs, inflation, trade and growth. At the moment, unemployment is coming down, inflation is falling, growth is robust and the trade deficit is stable, albeit uncomfortably large. Even an economy as riddled with structural problems as Britain’s hits a sweet spot from time to time, and this is one of them.

With an election just over a year away, Osborne is in the happy position of being able to say that the decisions he has taken are at last paying off. The likelihood is that 2014 will be as good as it gets, but given that 2014 is a pre-election year, the chancellor is in a much better place than he was 12 months ago, when all the talk was of a triple-dip recession.

Carney’s job is made a lot easier by falling price pressure. The unexpectedly rapid drop in joblessness has complicated things for the Bank of England, which said back in August that it would only start to mull over an increase in interest rates once unemployment has fallen to 7%. That now looks likely to happen imminently, much earlier than the 2016 date originally pencilled in by Threadneedle Street, but Carney and his colleagues on the monetary policy committee will now be able to say that on target inflation means shrinking dole queues are consistent with 0.5% borrowing costs. Interest rates remain on hold.

As for the rest of us, the problem for the past few years has been that prices have been rising more rapidly than earnings. Real wages, the value of what our pay packets buy us after inflation is taken into account, are down by almost 8% since the start of 2009: a sizeable cut in living standards. Prices are still rising at double the rate of earnings but the gap is smaller than it was a year ago and there is a good chance that at some point in 2014 a tighter labour market and a further drift down in inflation will see real wages start to rise. It will, of course, take years to recoup the losses suffered over the past five years, which is why for the public dropping inflation is as yet only modestly good news.

Updated at 11.13am GMT

10.50am GMT

Samuel Tombs of Capital Economics points out that some of this winter's energy price rises will be reversed this spring, once environmental levies are moved onto general taxation.

Tombs also reckons that food price inflation will continue to ease in 2014, given that agricultural commodity prices fell last year, predicting:

CPI inflation looks likely to spend more time below the 2% target than above it in 2014, helping real earnings to finally recover.

Updated at 10.50am GMT

10.31am GMT

Howard Archer of IHS Global insight sums up the key details:

Inflation was primarily brought down in December by an appreciable moderation in the year-on-year increase in food and non-alcoholic drinks, as well as lower prices for recreational goods & services.

This outweighed a rise in petrol prices and a limited upward impact from gas and electricity prices. Core inflation dipped to 1.7% in December from 1.8% in November.

As mentioned at 10.01am, the full impact of the latest round of inflation-busting gas and electricity price rises have not yet been felt in the inflation data.

Updated at 10.31am GMT

10.28am GMT

Key event

David Kern, chief economist at the British Chambers of Commerce (BCC), hopes that calls for the Bank of England to consider raising interest rates will relent, now that inflation is finally on target:

It is good news to see inflation fall to its 2% target for the first time since 2009, and should ease the pressure on businesses and consumers.

With inflation likely to remain at these levels during most of 2014, the unjustified demand in some quarters for interest rate increases should relent. In the meantime, the MPC needs to maintain its two-pronged approach with forward guidance on interest rates, and a continued commitment to keeping inflation at its 2% target.

10.20am GMT

UK inflation rate falls - early reaction

Here's a round-up of instant Twitter reaction to the news that the UK consumer prices index has fallen to 2%, the Bank of England's target, for the first time in over four years.

Updated at 10.57am GMT

10.11am GMT

David Cameron tweets....

10.09am GMT

Here's more details of today's inflation data:

  • The latest figures showed the usual month-on-month rise in the cost of food and alcoholic beverages from November to December was the smallest it has been since 2006.
  • It meant the annual rate of inflation in the sector slowed to 1.9%, the lowest rate since May 2010, indicating an easing in the usual pressure on household Christmas budgets.
  • Main downward contributions to this came from fruit and meat, while the price of fish was lower in December compared with November.
  • Meanwhile coffee, tea and cocoa were cheaper last month than they were the year before, though inflation for bread and cereals accelerated.
  • Games, toys and hobbies also saw price falls as Christmas approached, with reductions in computer games made for older platforms. 
  • Rising petrol prices had an upward effect on inflation, but the increase in the rate of air fares was lower than in 2012. 

(via PA).

Updated at 10.13am GMT

10.05am GMT

Labour: Cost of living crisis is not fixed

Labour MP Catherine McKinnell MP, shadow economic secretary to the Treasury, insists that today's inflation data is no reason to celebrate, given the ongoing cost of living crisis faced by many. 

“This small fall in the inflation rate is welcome, but with prices still rising more than twice as fast as wages the cost-of-living crisis continues. After three damaging years of flatlining, working people are on average £1600 a year worse off under the Tories.

“What we need is Labour's plan to tackle the cost-of-living crisis and earn our way to higher living standards for the many and not just a few.

“Labour would freeze energy bills until 2017 while we reform the energy market, make work pay by expanding free childcare for working parents and get at least 200,000 homes built a year by 2020.

“By opposing all these measures and giving a huge tax cut to people earning over £150,000 David Cameron has shown he only stands up for a privileged few.”

Updated at 10.09am GMT

10.01am GMT

Energy price rises not fully priced in

Today's data may not show the full effect of the winter increases in energy bills.

The Office for National Statistics says:

The first tranche of the expected winter price increases for gas and electricity entered the index
this month. The overall size of the price increase in December 2013 was slightly larger than a year earlier resulting in a small upward contribution to inflation.

9.58am GMT

The latest inflation data is online here.

9.51am GMT

Duncan Weldon of the TUC is swift to point out that real wages are still falling.

An inflation rate of 2% may be "on target", but with real wages growth of under 1% it means incomes are still shrinking.

9.46am GMT

Graph: UK's soaraway inflation

This graph shows how Britain's inflation rate has run over the Bank of England's 2% target for most of the last decade -- topping 5% in both 2008 and 2011.

That was a principle cause of the squeeze on living standards, given wage growth was so modest once the financial crisis began.

9.42am GMT

Here's the key points on today's UK inflation data, confirming that food prices pushed the cost of living down, countering the rise in energy bills.

  • The Consumer Prices Index (CPI) grew by 2.0% in the year to December 2013, down from 2.1% in November.

  • The largest contributions to the fall in the rate came from prices for food & non-alcoholic beverages and recreational goods & services. These were partially offset by an upward contribution from motor fuels.

  • The overall price increase for gas and electricity in December 2013 was slightly larger than the rises a year earlier resulting in a small upward contribution to inflation.

9.40am GMT

UK Treasury hails fall in inflation

The UK Treasury has welcomed the news that UK inflation has, at last, dropped to 2%.

A HM Treasury Spokesperson said:

Today’s data - which show inflation has returned to its target and fallen to its lowest level for four years - is another sign that the government’s long term economic plan is working.

But the job is not done and times remain tough for many people. So an important part of the government’s plan is helping hardworking people be more financially secure by increasing the tax free personal allowance and freezing fuel duty and council tax.

9.36am GMT

UK inflation hits lowest since November 2o09

This is the first time since 2009 that the UK inflation rate has hit the official target of 2% mandated by the Treasury. 

The Office for National Statistics reported that prices rose by just 0.4% month-on-month in December.

Inflation was pushed down by lower food and recreation costs, while energy costs rose during the month (as higher fuel tariffs hit consumers).

It's a welcome surprise -- City economists had expected the Consumer Prices Index to remain at 2.1%.

The other measure of inflation, the Retail Prices Index, came in at 2.7%

The news has sent the pound falling back to $1.641, having mysteriously jumped before the news broke. 

9.30am GMT

UK inflation data released

Breaking: UK inflation has fallen to 2.0%, the Bank of England's official target. 

9.29am GMT

Interesting newsflash on Reuters....

14-Jan-2014 09:27 - STERLING RISES TO $1.6445 FROM $1.6413 AHEAD OF UK INFLATION DATA 

9.21am GMT

Top hats off to Moss Bros too -- the once-struggling purveyor of formalwear has promised shareholders an increased dividend after growing sales by almost 13% in the final four months of 2013.

And it could also emulate ASOS's success online, with Cantor Fitzgerald retail analyst Freddie George saying:

"The major attraction of the company is the potential for the development of the retail online platform".

Assuming you already know your vital measurements, I guess....

9.04am GMT

Online clothing retailer ASOS has underlined the power of the Internet by reporting a 38% jump in sales over the Christmas trading period.

It's relentless focus on celebrities, and the endorsement of Samantha Cameron, also helped, writes my colleague Sean Farrell:

Asos targets "fashion-forward twenty-somethings" keen to emulate the styles of celebrities such as Kate Moss and Cara Delevingne. David Cameron's forty-something wife Samantha wore a £42 Asos dress to watch the prime minister's conference speech in October.

Asos unveils strong Christmas trading with sales up 38%

8.41am GMT

The Libor rate-rigging scandal has taken another twist, with three former Rabobank traders being charged in the US with plotting to manipulate the global interest rate.

Paul Robson, a Briton, Paul Thompson, an Australian, Tetsuya Motomura of Japan were charged on Monday with conspiracy to commitwire fraud and bank fraud, as well as two counts of wire fraud, according to a complaint filed in Manhattan federal court.

None of the men are in US custody, a court official said.

Three Rabobank traders charged in US with five-year plot to fix Libor

8.38am GMT

UK inflation preview

The UK inflation rate is expected to remain at a four-year low of 2.1% in December (we get the official data in under hour's time,), which would mean the squeeze on real wages continues.

Economics reporter Katie Allen explains that while energy bills went up last month, prices in the shops were cut as retailers tried to lure customers:

Deep pre-Christmas discounting and a slowdown in food price rises will probably have offset energy bill hikes and left inflation relatively benign last month, economists said.

Official data due on Tuesday morning is expected to show inflation held at November's four-year low of 2.1%, according to the consensus in a Reuters poll of economists. The highest estimate of the consumer price index measure (CPI) is for 2.3% and the lowest for 1.8%, which would mark the first reading below the Bank of England's 2% target since November 2009.

The wider retail price index (RPI) measure, which includes housing costs and is typically used to set pay deals, is expected to tick up to 2.7% from 2.6% in November.

Here's her preview: Inflation expected to hold steady at four-year low

Updated at 8.44am GMT

8.27am GMT

The big corporate news overnight was that US media giant Time Warner Cable had rejected a hostile takeover bid worth $37bn (or more than $60bn if you include debt).

The bid, from billionaire John Malone's Charter Communications, could kick off a lively battle for the future of Time Warner. Here's the full story:

Time Warner Cable: Charter goes hostile with $37bn bid

Updated at 8.27am GMT

8.23am GMT

Hawkish Fed members also push shares down

Markets are fell because more hawkish members of the US Federal Reserve have indicated that they are still keen to cut back on the US stimulus programme, despite last weak's jobs data showing a worrying rise in American's quitting the labour market altogether.

 So argues CMC's Michael Hewson, who writes:

Since Friday’s disappointing payrolls report we’ve heard from a number of Fed policymakers who insisted that any decision to taper further would not be swayed by last week’s numbers with Atlanta Fed President Dennis Lockhart following St. Louis Fed member James Bullard by saying that he would continue to support further reductions in stimulus. 

This seems to have accounted for the sharp sell-off seen late yesterday evening which saw the S&P500 post its worst day in two months, as the dial starts to shift away from what had been until recently a one way bet on stock markets.

Given that this year’s voting members now include the rather more hawkish Dallas Fed’s Richard Fisher and Charles Plosser of the Philadelphia Fed, the prospect of another reduction of stimulus at the end of this month, set against rather lofty valuations has seen investors decide to take some money off the table in a week that sees US earnings start to come in thick and fast starting with JP Morgan this afternoon.

Given that Plosser and Fisher are also due to speak later this afternoon on the economic outlook it probably won’t take a genius to figure out that they could well be hawkish in any comments they make with respect to stimulus reduction, and this could well have been another factor behind yesterday’s weakness, along with Goldman Sachs suggesting that markets could be in line for a 10% correction.

Updated at 8.23am GMT

8.20am GMT

It's a broad-based selloff in London this morning. All but four members of the FTSE 100 have lost ground, but there are no huge fallers. Here's the worst performers so far:

8.15am GMT

European markets fall in early trading

European stock markets are in the red at the start of trading, following the Nikkei's 3.1% slide earlier today.

The FTSE 100 fell 0.8%, shedding around 55 points to 6702. There are bigger losses on the German DAX, which fell 1.3% in early trading., while the Spanish and Italian markets are down around 1%.

Mike van Dulken, Head of Research at Accendo Markets, says that the selloff is partly due to: 

Increased concern over US equity valuations ahead ofQ4 earnings season derived from a Goldman Sachs report stating that the S&P 500 multiples were lofty by almost any measure and more expansion will be difficult to achieve.

Updated at 8.22am GMT

7.55am GMT

Nikkei suffers biggest fall in five months

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of events across the financial markets, the global economy, the eurozone and the business world.

A hefty selloff in Japan has seen the Nikkei suffer its biggest one-day fall in five months, as investors appear to suffer a wobble in confidence.

Japanese traders were in bearish mood today, with the Nikkei shedding 489 points, or almost 3.1%, to a one-month low of 15,422 as traders ditched shares after last night's tumble on Wall Street.

As IG's Chris Weston puts it:

 The Nikkei has been savaged, with the index playing catch up after being closed yesterday.

Yesterday's rally in the yen (when Japanese stock traders were on holiday) hit exporters.

Australia's ASX 200 fared little better, sliding 1.5% as its mining and resource stocks took a hammering (many losing over 5%). 

While gold has risen near a one-month high, around $1,252 per ounce.

And share are expected to drop in Europe this morning -- with the main indices being called down around 0.8%.

So what happened?

Well, there's no single trigger overnight, but investors appear to be more jittery about company profits as US corporate reporting season kicks off in earnest today (with JP Morgan, America's largest bank, publishing results).

Crédit Agricole suggested that:

Worries ahead of fourth quarter earnings releases and perhaps concerns about the economy in the wake of the disappointing US December jobs report weighed on US equities overnight.

Several mid-size firms posted unimpressive results yesterday (see SodaStream's profit warning) - so those who argued that the markets had got ahead of themselves are feeling rather vindicated.

Especially after Goldman Sachs analysts warned yesterday that the US S&P 500 index was too high and almost certain to fall (and when Goldman says it, people tend to listen).

One Paris-based trader told Reuters that the markets are bracing for a chilly dose of realism:

We've been focusing a lot on macro data, but the real test is coming, with the earnings season starting, and the market might have been too optimistic about earnings recovery.

And Friday's weak US jobs data seems to have finally sunk in, causing the Dow Jones Industrial Average to shed 1.1% last night:

Ian Williams of Peel Hunt commented:

The major indices seemed to suffer a delayed reaction to the payrolls report, with the markdown accelerating late in the session and ending in the worst daily losses since 7 November.

So, it could be a lively day ahead -- with all eyes on JP Morgan around lunchtime UK time.

We also get the latest UK inflation data at 9.30am -- a month ago, the CPI fell surprisingly to 2.1%, easing the pressure on the Bank of England over its loose monetary policy.

And Francois Hollande is due to give a big speech on his economic programme later today, outlining how he will tackle problems in the French economy. The president may have other things on his mind, though.....

Michael Hewson of CMC Markets points out:

In Europe the French President Francois Hollande is due to give a press conference outlining his plans to try and revive the weak French economy. Unfortunately for him the media are more likely to be interested in details of his private life after weekend revelations of an alleged affair with an actress.

We'll be tracking the main events through the day...

fields.bodyText: Over in Greece the government has announced it had achieved the much-cherished target of posting a primary surplus last year which will, it says, make it eligible for debt relief. Helena Smith reports: After years of pain-staking spending cuts Greece’s central government posted a primary budget surplus of just under €700m in 2013, Athens’ deputy finance minister Christos Staikouras announced in parliament today. As prime minister Antonis Samaras prepared to fly to Strasbourg where he will formally unveil Greece’s EU presidency plans to the European Parliament, Staikouras said the country was now on target to achieve a total primary budget surplus of around €812m, or 0.4% of gross domestic product at the general government level. Although general government data are not expected to be released for another month “all the indicators show that we will exceed our target,” the minister said, adding that once that happened Athens would be in the market for serious debt relief consideration. With the country’s debt burden at an untenable €360bn (more than 175% of GDP) officials say economic recovery will be high nigh impossible until the issue is resolved. Greece’s EU partners and the International Monetary Fund, which have been keeping the nation afloat, have promised to broach the potentially explosive topic once Athens achieves a primary surplus. Samaras' fragile two-party coalition has pledged to redress slashed pensions and benefits for Greece’s most vulnerable with the extra funds, but Staikouras as is the wont of all politicians in Greece these days avoided going into specifics. Aside from the recession in the province traders in cities such as Belfast also had to bear the brunt of ongoing loyalist flag protests in the commercial heart of the city including key shopping days coming up to Christmas. Annalisa Piazza at Newedge Strategy said: US retail sales came in at a modest 0.2% month on month in December from a downward revised 0.4% the prior month. The downward revision for the latter leaves the overall picture for the fourth quarter of 2013 in line with expectations. James Knightley at ING said: With consumer confidence improving and the general state of the economy looking in decent shape, notwithstanding the soft payrolls number last Friday, we remain upbeat on consumer spending prospects and look for the US economy to grow by 3% this year and the Fed taper to continue through to 4Q. Another Wall Street bank, Wells Fargo, has beaten forecasts with a 10% jump in fourth-quarter profits. It made $5.6bn, or $1 per share, in the last three months of 2013. And on that note, I'm handing over to my colleague Nick Fletcher. Our City editor Jill Treanor has digested today's fourth-quarter and full-year results from JP Morgan, and flags up that average pay rose across the bank last year despite the stream of legal charges and bills. She reports: A wave of legal costs and regulatory penalties have dented the profitability of America’s biggest bank JP Morgan and ended a run of record profits. Becoming the first major US bank to report its results for last year - Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and Bank of America report later this week - JP Morgan admitted its full year profits had fallen 16% to $18bn after a year in which has paid out penalties of around $20bn in total. The fines have related to the subprime mortgage crisis and its London Whale trading incident in 2012 and Jamie Dimon, who is both chairman and chief executive of the bank, said he was pleased to put “some significant issues behind us this quarter” after reaching settlements with regulators. The bank revealed that despite the profits slump the average pay for its 251,000 staff was $122,653 in 2013 - up from $118,000 a year earlier - although within its investment banking arm the average pay was $207,368, down 5% on 2012. The most recent was last week when it paid a record $2bn to settle charges it had knowingly ignored evidence that convicted fraudster Bernard Madoff’s massive Ponzi scheme was “too good to be true.” “It was in the best interests of our company and shareholders for us to accept responsibility, resolve these issues and move forward. This will allow us to focus on what we are here for: serving our clients and communities around the world. We remained focused on building our four leading franchises, which all continued to deliver strong underlying performance, for the quarter and the year,” he said. In the fourth quarter profits fell by 7% to $5.3bn after taking a knock from $1.1bn of legal expenses. But in the third quarter the bank had slumped to its first quarterly loss under Dimon as a result of $9.2bn of legal expenses. Over on Wall Street, JP Morgan's legal travails have hit its profits again -- and its investment bank didn't have a great quarter either. JP Morgan kicked off the bank reporting season by announcing that its net income slid by 7% in the last quarter, down to $5.28bn from $5.69bn a year ago. The results are complicated by the company's latest brushes with regulators -- it just agreed to pay $1.7bn (£1bn) to compensate victims of the Bernard Madoff fraud, the latest in a stream of legal bills. CEO Jamie Dimon argued that the bank has made progress dealing with its problems. saying: We are pleased to have made progress on our control, regulatory and litigation agendas and to have put some significant issues behind us this quarter. Skimming the results, JPM's consumer banking division had a good quarter -- profits on mortgage banking rose 34%. Investment bank profits tumbled by 57%, although if various one-off accountancy changes are excluded they dropped by a less dramatic 11%. There are also signs of a slowdown on the trading desks -- fixed income (ie bonds) revenue dropped to $3.2bn, from $4.08bn. Equity markets revenue (such as share trading) fell to $873 million, from $1.3 billion a year earlier. Speaking of London house prices.... we have fresh evidence, not that we needed it, that London's super-rich remain untouched by the cost of living squeeze. A new tower block is to be thrown up alongside The Shard*, to provide accommodation for well-heeled workers in the Capital. And as fastFT flags up, there are 10 apartments up for sale within The Shard itself, "rumoured to be priced at £50m each." Not clear that any have been sold yet, but the developers must be confident of demand if they're building another (smaller) tower next door. The FT's Kate Allen wrote: The new tower, being unveiled at a public consultation today, will include 150 apartments and retail space, as well as a roof garden. The project is being developed by Sellar Property Group in partnership with the state of Qatar. * - which offers astoundingly beautiful views, only partly because you can't see the Shard from inside While the headline inflation rate eased back to 2.0%, house prices have been rising more than twice as fast, according to fresh data this morning. Strong demand in the south of England drove average house prices up by 5.3% over the last year, the ONS reported. First-time buyers were hit harder, paying 6.4% more than in 2012. My colleague Hilary Osborne reports: The Office for National Statistics said that new entrants to the housing market paid an average of £187,000 during the month – £14,000 more than in the same month of 2012. The average price paid by movers was higher, at £284,000, which was 5.3% up on 12 months previously, while the average increase across the board was 5.4%. And London prices led the way, rising by 11.6%. More here: House prices up across the UK, says ONS Here's our news story on today's fall in inflation: Inflation finally falls to Bank of England's 2% target A recap for new readers. • Britain's inflation rate has finally returned to the government's 2% target, bringing some relief to households and businesses after the long squeeze on living standards. The Office for National Statistics reported that prices, as measured by the consumer prices index, rose by just 2.0% annually in December. It's the lowest rate since late 2009, and means inflation is in line with the Bank of England's goal. • Food prices rose by less, the ONS said, while the cost of toys and computer games dropped - suggesting heavy discounting by shops in the run-up to Christmas. This pushed down CPI, despite energy bills rising as the first winter tariffs hit customers. • The government hailed the news, with a Treasury spokesman saying that easing inflation meant the UK economy was recovering. Prime minister David Cameron tweeted that hard working families -- a key target demographic for Westminster -- were benefitting. • But real wages are continuing to shrink, given average pay packets are rising by less than 1%. Labour warned that more needs to be done to help families, such as an energy price freeze and making more free childcare available for working parents. Catherine McKinnell MP, shadow economic secretary to the Treasury, insists that today's inflation data is no reason to celebrate, given the ongoing cost of living crisis faced by many. This small fall in the inflation rate is welcome, but with prices still rising more than twice as fast as wages the cost-of-living crisis continues. After three damaging years of flatlining, working people are on average £1600 a year worse off under the Tories. • Business leaders welcomed the news, with the BCC arguing that there's no need for the Bank of England to bow to pressure for an early rate rise. • But as Larry Elliott, our economics editor points out, today's big winners are George Osborne and BoE governor Mark Carney. Most people have suffered a hefty fall in real income since the crisis began -- real wages need to turn positive before the damage can be repaired. Today's drop in the Consumer Prices Index to 2% is particularly welcome because high inflation had become the "new normal", says Andrew Sentance, senior economic adviser at PwC. Sentance (a former interest-rate setter at the Bank of England) warns that inflationary pressure could intensify through the year. ﻿It’s no coincidence that the fall in inflation over the past year has accompanied a pick-up in growth. Lower price increases ease the squeeze on consumers and allow them to increase spending. Now that inflation has returned to target, the challenge will be to keep it there. Stronger growth here in the UK could push up wage costs and a rebound in the global economy is likely to push up energy, food and commodity prices once again. So we cannot be sure that this return to the inflation target will be sustained through 2014. Our economics editor, Larry Elliott, writes that today's fall in the UK inflation rate to the official target of 2.0% for the first time since 2009 is good for chancellor George Osborne and Bank of England governor Mark Carney. It's "moderately good for the rest of us", he adds. Falling inflation is welcome news for the Tories with an election around the corner, and also takes pressure off Carney to raise interest rates. But years of high inflation have made a serious dent in living standards - today's inflation data doesn't fix that. Larry says: The small decline last month from the 2.1% recorded in November doesn’t sound much, but December saw an increase in petrol prices and the first tranche of price hikes from the “Big 6” energy companies. Price cuts from supermarkets and early Christmas discounting by over-stocked high street retailers helped matters. The downward trend is likely to continue. Core inflation, the cost of living minus increases in food and fuel prices, dipped from 1.8% to 1.7%, while the cost of goods leaving factory gates – an early sign of price pressures – was up 1% on year earlier. A stronger pound will bear down on the UK’s bill for imports. It’s pretty clear why this is good news for the chancellor. There are four key measures of how well the economy is doing at a big-picture level: jobs, inflation, trade and growth. At the moment, unemployment is coming down, inflation is falling, growth is robust and the trade deficit is stable, albeit uncomfortably large. Even an economy as riddled with structural problems as Britain’s hits a sweet spot from time to time, and this is one of them. With an election just over a year away, Osborne is in the happy position of being able to say that the decisions he has taken are at last paying off. The likelihood is that 2014 will be as good as it gets, but given that 2014 is a pre-election year, the chancellor is in a much better place than he was 12 months ago, when all the talk was of a triple-dip recession. Carney’s job is made a lot easier by falling price pressure. The unexpectedly rapid drop in joblessness has complicated things for the Bank of England, which said back in August that it would only start to mull over an increase in interest rates once unemployment has fallen to 7%. That now looks likely to happen imminently, much earlier than the 2016 date originally pencilled in by Threadneedle Street, but Carney and his colleagues on the monetary policy committee will now be able to say that on target inflation means shrinking dole queues are consistent with 0.5% borrowing costs. Interest rates remain on hold. As for the rest of us, the problem for the past few years has been that prices have been rising more rapidly than earnings. Real wages, the value of what our pay packets buy us after inflation is taken into account, are down by almost 8% since the start of 2009: a sizeable cut in living standards. Prices are still rising at double the rate of earnings but the gap is smaller than it was a year ago and there is a good chance that at some point in 2014 a tighter labour market and a further drift down in inflation will see real wages start to rise. It will, of course, take years to recoup the losses suffered over the past five years, which is why for the public dropping inflation is as yet only modestly good news. Samuel Tombs of Capital Economics points out that some of this winter's energy price rises will be reversed this spring, once environmental levies are moved onto general taxation. Tombs also reckons that food price inflation will continue to ease in 2014, given that agricultural commodity prices fell last year, predicting: CPI inflation looks likely to spend more time below the 2% target than above it in 2014, helping real earnings to finally recover. Howard Archer of IHS Global insight sums up the key details: Inflation was primarily brought down in December by an appreciable moderation in the year-on-year increase in food and non-alcoholic drinks, as well as lower prices for recreational goods & services.
